criterion_text: Recent change in gastrointestinal medications
Subjects hypomotility disorders of the gastrointestinal tract including but not limited to Ileus.
Gastrointestinal ulceration
Clinically significant bleeding within two weeks prior to randomization (e.g., gastrointestinal (GI) bleeding, intracranial hemorrhage)
Chronic or acute GI disorders resulting in diarrhea of any severity grade.
Gastrointestinal disorder affecting absorption (e.g., gastrectomy, active peptic ulcer disease within last 3 months, inflammatory bowel disease)
Patients with inflammatory bowel disease.
Acute urinary tract infection.
Known presence of fulminant CDI, including hypotension, severe ileus or GI obstruction or incipient toxic megacolon
GI perforation/fistula
Active or recent history of gastrointestinal perforations, ulcers, fistulas or abscesses
Known gastrointestinal (GI) disease or GI procedure that could interfere with the oral absorption or tolerance of study drugs including difficulty swallowing
Peptic ulcer disease
Presence of any gastrointestinal tract malignancy
History of abdominal fistula, gastrointestinal perforation within 6 months prior to study enrollment
Subjects with acute liver disease or active peptic ulcer disease.
Patients with evidence of active septicemia, severe infection, gastrointestinal bleeding or severe gastrointestinal symptoms requiring medical or surgical therapy
Patients with a history of or current gastric ulcers
Subject with active peptic ulceration
Inflammatory bowel disease or proctitis
Clinically significant gastrointestinal disorders
Significant gastrointestinal (GI) disease, previous major gastric/bowel surgery, difficulty swallowing, or malabsorption syndrome
History of gastrointestinal bleeding from peptic ulcer disease
History of abdominal fistula, gastrointestinal perforation, or intra-abdominal abscess within 6 months prior to Day 1.
Active gastrointestinal blood loss
Gastrointestinal ailments that may alter the absorption of oral medications (i.e. bowel obstruction, short-gut syndrome).
Acquired or congenital gastrointestinal disease
Active bleeding or high risk for bleeding (e.g. known acute gastrointestinal ulcer)
Intestinal atresia or perforation
